column3: Conservation and Enhancement of Pacific Salmonids in the Nanaimo Watershed
column4: Pursue enhancement goals and objectives for each brood year outlined in the approved Integrated Fisheries Management Plan Production Plan for the Nanaimo and Chemainus River watersheds. To support stock rebuilding, raise and release up to: ·  225,000 summer run and 425,000 fall run Nanaimo chinook ;  67,500 Chemainus chinook salmon ; 200,000 Nanaimo coho ; To support harvest access, raise and release up to:  900,000 Nanaimo chum ; 1,000,000 pink salmon

column3: Conservation and Enhancement of Pacific Salmonids in the Nanaimo Watershed
column4: To fulfill the purpose of promoting conservation and enchancement in the Nanaimo River area, the NRSS undertakes and supports public education and outreach activities. The activities range from volunteer participation in salmon enhancement activities and educational viewing opportunities, to school programs and salmon fry release opportunities for the public and students. Most stewardship activities align with the timing of salmon enhancement activities across the year.
column9: Nanaimo River Stewardship Society,Community Donations,Volunteer labour,VIU Practicum

column3: Thornton Creek Hatchery: Conservation and Enhancement of Pacific Salmonids in Barkley Sound
column4: TCH supports conservation and rebuilding, and harvest enhancement objectives in the Ucluelet area watersheds, Toquaht watershed and enhancement activities in the Clayoquot Sound watersheds that include Tranquil and Upper Kennedy River watersheds. Year round tasks involve implementing best management practices of salmon culture techniques including Salmonid broodstock capture, holding, handling, sorting, spawning, incubation - (inventory, fungus treatments - salt, parasite S, shocking, picking (hand, machine), ponding, marking, flows, experiments, marking (otolith, clips, tags, other), rearing in raceways, channels, tubs, netpens/seapens (diet/growth, pond maintenance, water quality, flow), fish health management, treatment, biosecurity (internal, external), transport, release, adult and juvenile enumeration and sampling. Program preparation, monitoring, troubleshooting, maintenance and clean-up are ongoing tasks. Program strategic planning and broader facilities maintenance occur during periods of reduced biological activity.

column3: Thornton Creek Hatchery: Conservation and Enhancement of Pacific Salmonids in Barkley Sound
column4: Thornton Creek Hatchery works collaboratively with First Nations, volunteer community groups, municipal and federal governments, industry, educational institutions, and other stakeholder groups. The hatchery supports Community Involvement Program Stream to Sea Education programming, including Salmonids in the Classroom. Most stewardship activities align with the timing of salmon enhancement activities throughout the year.

column3: Operational Capacity Funding - 4x4 Pickup Truck Purchase
column4: The organization will purchase a 4x4 ½ ton pickup truck to replace its primary fisheries vehicle which is from 2005, and is worn out from 15 years of heavy use.

column3: Somass Watershed Sockeye Salmon Enumeration
column4: This project focuses on the Somass River watershed. The Somass is one of the largest sockeye rivers in B.C.  It is a crucial component of the Organization's food, social and ceremonial catch as well as the other five First Nations in the Barkley Sound Watershed.  The enumeration work has been conducted by the Organization and DFO over the past 18 years. This activity seeks to continue and build on that work.  The work focuses on the technical aspect of collaborative management, and involves the collection, sampling and dissemination of the Sockeye enumeration data. A biologist has been hired to work with the Organization's Members to help achieve this goal. The short term result of this work will be increased capacity regarding technical science methodology. The Organization sees this as a continuing step to achieving the longer term goal of enabling members to understand, analyze, and apply data to support their interests in collaborative resource management regarding the watershed and approach areas. The goal of this project is to increase the capacity of the Organization to engage in an expanded collaborative relationship with DFO and ensure sustainable management of fish in the Organization's asserted traditional area.

column3: Fall Salmon (non-Sockeye) Stock Assessment
column4: The Organization works with DFO to conduct adult salmon enumeration and biological sampling at the Stamp, Sproat River and Great Central Lake fish ways from May until November. Work is done under contract with DFO South Coast Stock Assessment Unit (Diana Dobson). The Organization's AFS funded guardian (non-designated) and fisheries manager assist other Hupacasath staff with this work as well as interact with DFO assessment staff regularly throughout the duration of the program. 2.

column3: Food, Social and Ceremonial Fisheries Management - Hupacasath First Nation
column4: The Organizations Fisheries staff engages their community members to develop their fishing plans. Hupacasath's FSC Somass salmon fishing plans are part of their overall Tsu-ma-uss Fisheries Agreement with DFO and their non-salmon FSC fishing plans are part of this Agreement. Hupacasath Fisheries regularly engages and communicates Hupacasath FSC fishing plans and opportunities to its Members. The Organizations Fisheries staff provide catch monitoring information to DFO throughout the year according to agreed upon Schedules.

column3: Surplus funding - Juvenile Sockeye Stock Assessment Acoustic Trawl Surveys
column4: Hupacasath Fisheries has been conducting ATS surveys for the past three seasons. These surveys are an essential tool in assessing the productivity of sockeye nursery lakes and provide data that is directly used in forecasting the adult returns. Locally Hupacasath FN has been conducting two surveys at each Great Central Lake and Sproat Lake annually, but with the recent declines in the stocks in both systems the importance of monitoring these populations has grown. We are proposing two additional surveys at each lake be conducted to ensure accurate pre-smolt estimates can be generated and any mortality events in the lakes be identified. The cost for these additional surveys is outlined below. To date the Hupacasath Fisheries department has not completed any surveys in Henderson Lake due to access issues, but with the recent development of a smaller, more mobile set up, there is an opportunity to restart these surveys. One survey will be funded within this agreement. This survey will provide very important data for DFO stock assessment to accurately forecast the sockeye returns to Henderson Lake. The cost to conduct this survey is detailed below.

column3: Surplust funding - Fisheries Program Truck (Capital Acquisition)
Spring and Early Summer Salmon Enumeration at Sproat River Fishway and Stamp Falls Fishway
column4: To estimate escapement of salmon using video counts from the Sproat and Stamp Falls fishways. Counting operations will run from mid-May through mid-Aug, and a sub-sample of videos from both sites will be reviewed to identify fish to species and estimate the portion of marked fish. Biological samples will also be collected (2-3 times per week from fish at both sites to estimate the age and sex composition of escapement).

column3: Rotary Screw Trap (PST)
column4: To hire a company to begin construction of a rotary screw trap (RST). Components to construct are a floating fish rotating screen including a steel trailer; aluminum pontoon base, aluminum fish catch box, and an aluminum cones catching drum. The full estimated cost to build the RST is $51,450.00 plus taxes. The $9,345.00 will be spent this fiscal and the remaining balance will be covered in the 2021-2022 fiscal year. The RST will be used for existing projects to estimate the abundance of the Smolt Out-Migration through Robertson Creek and Sproat River.

column3: FSC Salmon Catch Monitoring of all Metlakatla and designated non-members fishing (under Metlakatla designation) in the approach waters to the Skeena River (not including sub-areas 4-12 and 4-15)
column4: MAR will conduct routine catch monitoring to encourage compliance with the conditions of communal licences.  The MAR staff will conduct on-grounds inspection of personal and vessel designations, observe catch methods, and monitor harvest levels.  MAR operates a FSC salmon validation and distribution program from June - September to assist with FSC needs.  Through this program, salmon are distributed to band members, and dockside validators record by-catch and salmon catch numbers from each vessel that delivers to the program.  Landing stations will be located in Metlakatla and at Metlakatla's Fisheries dock in Prince Rupert.  Records of validation; such as dates, vessels, number of salmon, and distribution to membership will be maintained.

column3: Stock Assessment
column4: 1.Coldwater River Coho: NWSFA will undertake an adult Coho enumeration project at the Coldwater River fence.  The project will involve enumeration by sex, as well as adipose clip and CWT status through the utilization of a trap box and Sonar technology.  CWT status will be assessed by the removal of marked fish for sampling. Fish released upstream of the trap box will be externally marked to determine if fish have been previously handled. This will assist in the calculation of clip rates from upstream sampling efforts as clip rates will change with the removal of clipped fish at the fence.  Specific technical detail of this project can be found in Supplemental Conditions/Provisions for Fiscal Year 2020-2021. 2.Nicola River and tributaries Coho: As time, budget, and weather conditions allow, other known Coho spawning areas will be checked, and counts of adult Coho performed 3 times over the 3 weeks of expected peak spawn:  Nicola River near Dot ranch; upstream of Nicola and Coldwater confluence to Nicola lake dam and upper Nicola River; plus tributaries such as Guichon Creek, Clapperton Creek, Spahomin Creek, Quilchena Creek and Chutter Ranch side channel. 3.Nicola River Chinook:  NWSFA staff will carry out the carcass recovery and sampling work associated with mark/recapture activities.  Carcass recovery activities will be undertaken in the Nicola River mainstem between the outlet of Nicola Lake and the Dot Trestle, lower Clapperton Creek, Coldwater River downstream of the IR#1 bridge, and Spius Creek downstream of Little Box Canyon. If appropriate (budget- and fish-presence dependant), the upper Nicola River between Nicola Lake and Douglas Lake, and Spahomin Creek, will also be inspected. Other possible Chinook refuge habitat will be surveyed as time, budget and weather conditions allow.

column3: FSC Catch Monitoring (Siska)
column4: Under contract with the STC, the Siska Band will carry out in-person interviews with fishers to collect Food, Social and Ceremonial (FSC) salmon catch information at Siska fishing sites. Crews will also collect biological samples as agreed to with DFO. Catch data is submitted to DFO weekly.  Meetings occur pre-season with DFO for the purpose of training and in-season to share information, resolve issues of concern and facilitate effective coordination of catch monitoring and fishing activities.Specific tasks will include:1.A catch monitoring schedule will be completed by the Siska Band in collaboration with the NWSFA Fisheries Technologist and DFO.  DFO will lead  orientation(s) for monitors prior to start of the program which may include a site visit to fishing areas.2.Monitors will carry out the field data collection according to schedule and will report missed shifts or changes to the schedule to the Fisheries Technologist (or a designated NWSFA alternate staff as agreed to with DFO). The Fisheries Technologist (or alternate) will update DFO as soon as possible to enable schedule modification. Any conservation and protection concerns that monitors have during their shift will be reported to the Fisheries Technologist (or alternate) who will contact the appropriate DFO staff as soon as possible.3.During the program, the NWSFA Fisheries Technologist will verify that the data sheets match the schedule and will coordinate with Siska and/or DFO to address data quality concerns in-season.

column3: Stock Assessment and Fisheries Management- Ahousaht
column4: 1.Ahousaht Fisheries staff conducts escapement surveys according to a survey schedule developed with Ahousaht Fisheries, the Organizations Central Region Fisheries Biologist, the Ahousaht/ Fish Farm Enhancement Committee, and with DFO South Coast Stock Assessment staff. 2.With the assistance of external funding from Canadian Food Inspection agency (CFIA), Ahousaht Fisheries staff conducts bio-toxin monitoring.  AFS funding pays for Ahousaht Fisheries staff wages and related expenses to assist with the monitoring.  CFIA funding pays for Ahousaht Fisheries boat operating expenses and shipping of samples.3.Ahousaht Fisheries conduct general monitoring, and biological and enforcement surveys of Ahousaht Ha-houlthee and report issues or concerns to the community and relevant agencies.

column3: Stock Assessment and Fisheries Management-Ditidaht
column4: 1.Ditidaht Fisheries staff conducts escapement surveys according to survey schedule developed with DFO South Coast Stock Assessment and Ditidaht. a.Enumerate adult Hobiton River sockeye by installing and operating an adult salmon counting fence from April to June. b.Prepare the juvenile trap site and install Rotary Screw Trap (provided by DFO) with assistance from DFO South Coast Stock Assessment and Uu-a-thluk staff. c.Two to three Cheewaht salmon spawner surveys will occur from October to November. d.Nitinat Lake assessment fisheries:  using food and ceremonial fisheries and Nitinat hatchery chinook, chum and coho broodstock collections to gather information with DFO on run-timing, distribution and age structure of chinook, coho and chum returning to Nitinat Lake from August to November. AFS covers the wages of the Fisheries Manager and some boat and other equipment expenses.  Ditidaht uses internal funding to cover all other costs. 2.Nitinat Lake crab are monitored and assessed at least six times throughout the year.3.Ditidaht staff will work with the Organization's staff to develop and implement groundfish monitoring and assessment in DFO Statistical Areas 21/121.4.With the assistance of external funding from the Canada Food Inspection agency (CFIA), Ditidaht Fisheries staff conducts bio-toxin monitoring from May to October. AFS funding pays for Ditidaht Fisheries staff wages and related expenses to assist with the monitoring.  CFIA funding pays for Ditidaht Fisheries boat operating expenses and shipping of samples.5.Ditidaht Fisheries conduct general monitoring of Ditidaht Ha-houlthee and report issues or concerns to the community and relevant agencies.6.Ditidaht Fisheries staff works closely with the Nitinat hatchery staff with activities (e.g., salmon broodstock collections, towing net-pens, feeding net penned fish, etc). 7.Ditidaht Fisheries work with DFO and the Organization's staff to develop an Escapement Salmon Spawning Requirements (ESSR) agreement for Nitinat Lake chinook, coho and chum, where abundances are appropriate.8.Ditidaht Fisheries staff work with DFO for fall salmon stock assessment survey planning.

column3: Stock Assessment and Fisheries Management- Ehattesaht
column4: 1.Ehattesaht Fisheries staff conduct salmon and herring spawning surveys according to survey schedule developed with the Organization's Northern Region Fisheries Biologist and DFO South Coast Stock Assessment (for salmon surveys) as follows: a.Enumerate adult Tahtahtis (Zeballos) River hinkuuas (chum salmon) in September to mid-October by conducting weekly bank or snorkel counts to enumerate spawning salmon from the municipal campground at tidewater to and including the canyon tail spawning bed.  Observation data will be reported to DFO South Coast Stock Assessment  (cc DFO WCVI AFS Manager) on Stream Inspection Logs in-season.  The actual dates and method of reporting to DFO will be included in the AFS Year End Report.b.Ehattesaht staff will work with the Organization's staff to monitor herring spawn distribution, and any food and ceremonial herring fisheries in northern DFO Statistical Area 25.2.Ehattesaht Fisheries staff conduct general monitoring of Ehattesaht Ha-houlthee and report issues or concerns to the community and relevant agencies.3.Ehatteshat Fisheries staff conduct a feasibility study on restoring access for salmon above Zeballos River cascade or falls.4.Ehattesaht Fisheries staff participate in the operation of the Zeballos River hatchery and work closely with the DFO Community Advisor, members of the Zeballos Enhancement Society, youth and community members performing various activities (e.g., salmon broodstock collections, egg incubation, juvenile salmon rearing and releases and may participate in the future in feeding of net penned chum and other species as approved by DFO).5. Ehattesaht Fisheries staff participate in juvenile Chinook salmon micro-trolling sampling activities coordinated through DFO Science (Jessy Bokvist) including all required sampling protocol training.

column3: Stock Assessment and Fisheries Management- Hesquiaht
column4: 1.Hesquiaht Fisheries staff conduct salmon escapement surveys. 2.Hesquiaht Fisheries staff will construct new or re-establish old trails along side some of the streams that will undergo salmon escapement surveys.   3.Hesquiaht Fisheries staff will conduct general monitoring and biological surveys of Hesquiaht Ha-houlthee. 4.Hesquiaht Fisheries will continue to work with Central Westcoast Forest Society (CWFS) on stream restoration work for Ay-yi-sagh Creek, the extent of work completed will be dependent on external funding.  AFS funding pays for Hesquiaht Fisheries staff wages and related expenses, if funding is not available through CWFS.  CWFS pays for any other expenditures required for the project.  Hesquiaht Fisheries only participates in the work if funding is available by CWFS.5. Hesquiaht Fisheries staff will support the construction and installation of a counting fence at Purdon Creek and Hisnit Lake to enumerate adult salmon escapement.

column3: Stock Assessment and Fisheries Management- Mowachaht/Muchalaht
column4: 1.Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff conducts escapement surveys according to survey schedule developed with Uu-a-thluk Regional Biologist and DFO South Coast Stock Assessment staff. a.Enumerate Oktwanch River (Gold River) sockeye and Chinook at Burman River, visual surveys (2-3 surveys) from September to November. b.Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff will implement a bus route CREEL monitoring program for Gold River sockeye fisheries to estimate catch and effort by seine, dipnet and hook and line.2.With the assistance of external funding from the Canada Food Inspection agency (CFIA), Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff conduct bio-toxin monitoring from May to October. 3. Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff conduct general monitoring of Mowachaht/Muchalaht Ha-houlthee and report issues or concerns to the community and relevant agencies.4. Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff works closely with the Nootka Sound Watershed Society (NSWS) and Conuma hatchery staff (e.g., salmon collections, juvenile salmon releases and feeding net pen chinook and chum).5.Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff work with DFO and the Organization's staff on the planning and development of an Excess Salmon to Spawning Requirements (ESSR) agreement for Conuma River chinook, coho and chum if abundances are deemed sufficient.6.Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff works with DFO to coordinate for fall salmon stock assessment survey planning and information flow.

column3: Stock Assessment and Fisheries Management- Nuchatlaht
column4: 1.Nuchatlaht Fisheries staff will monitor, sound, and survey herring spawning waters.2.Nuchatlaht Fisheries staff will monitor and survey spawning streams for salmon.  Reporting live count and carcasses on 2 streams: Espinosa, Savey Creek (Owossista, and Mary Basin, if conditions permit). 3.Nuchatlaht staff will monitor spawning waters for both herring and salmon for activities that may impact spawning areas, such as upland activity disturbances that may affect water, sediment and large wood debris, cover in the "shore zone," and/or sedimentation of salmon spawning habitat.4.Nuchatlaht staff will plan protections for estuaries and watersheds from industrial activities in the form of Salmon Forest Conservation Areas in the Owiissta/Apple Creeks and the Shoomaht/Ransom Creek (Nuu-chah-nulth Salmon Forest Ecological Network watersheds).

column4: Following receipt of engineered design (in-kind contribution), Ehattesaht will oversee the Zeballos Community hatchery project to re-establish water supply, upgrade plumbing system including installation of circular tanks as well as improve biosecurity

column3: Operational Capacity Funding - Acquisition of office equipment, outboard motors and ATV (capital acquisition)-Hesquiaht
column4: 1.Hesquiaht will replace two computers in their fisheries office with appropriate laptops and software to support fisheries program office work, including allowing for remote video conferencing participation in meetings.2.Hesquiaht will purchase two 150 HP outboards to replace existing 300 HP single outboard 3.Hesquiaht will purchase an ATV for Fisheries Technician use

column3: Operational Capacity Funding - Steel Shelter Boat and Trailer Storage (Capital Infustructure)- Nuchatlaht
column4: Nuchatlaht will purchase a Steel warehouse building including overseeing the planning, development and construction phases.

column3: Operational Capacity Funding - Replacement of Fisheries Patrol Vessel (capital acquisition)-Tla-o-qui-aht
column4: Tla-o-qui-aht will purchase a new fisheries patrol vessel as a replacement to the inflatable rigid hull boat

column3: Operational Capacity Funding - Patrol Boat equipment and life raft (capital acquisition)- Ahousaht
column4: Ahousaht will purchase a stove, sink, heater and a new life raft for their fisheries patrol vessel.

column3: Stock Assessment and Fisheries Management- Ahousaht
column4: 1.Ahousaht Fisheries staff conducts escapement surveys according to a survey schedule developed with Ahousaht Fisheries, the Organizations Central Region Fisheries Biologist, the Ahousaht/ Fish Farm Enhancement Committee, and with DFO South Coast Stock Assessment staff. 2.With the assistance of external funding from Canadian Food Inspection agency (CFIA), Ahousaht Fisheries staff conducts bio-toxin monitoring.  AFS funding pays for Ahousaht Fisheries staff wages and related expenses to assist with the monitoring.  CFIA funding pays for Ahousaht Fisheries boat operating expenses and shipping of samples.3.Ahousaht Fisheries conduct general monitoring, and biological and enforcement surveys of Ahousaht Ha-houlthee and report issues or concerns to the community and relevant agencies.

column3: Stock Assessment and Fisheries Management-Ditidaht
column4: 1.Ditidaht Fisheries staff conducts escapement surveys according to survey schedule developed with DFO South Coast Stock Assessment and Ditidaht. a.Enumerate adult Hobiton River sockeye by installing and operating an adult salmon counting fence from April to June. b.Prepare the juvenile trap site and install Rotary Screw Trap (provided by DFO) with assistance from DFO South Coast Stock Assessment and Uu-a-thluk staff. c.Two to three Cheewaht salmon spawner surveys will occur from October to November. d.Nitinat Lake assessment fisheries:  using food and ceremonial fisheries and Nitinat hatchery chinook, chum and coho broodstock collections to gather information with DFO on run-timing, distribution and age structure of chinook, coho and chum returning to Nitinat Lake from August to November. AFS covers the wages of the Fisheries Manager and some boat and other equipment expenses.  Ditidaht uses internal funding to cover all other costs. 2.Nitinat Lake crab are monitored and assessed at least six times throughout the year.3.Ditidaht staff will work with the Organization's staff to develop and implement groundfish monitoring and assessment in DFO Statistical Areas 21/121.4.With the assistance of external funding from the Canada Food Inspection agency (CFIA), Ditidaht Fisheries staff conducts bio-toxin monitoring from May to October. AFS funding pays for Ditidaht Fisheries staff wages and related expenses to assist with the monitoring.  CFIA funding pays for Ditidaht Fisheries boat operating expenses and shipping of samples.5.Ditidaht Fisheries conduct general monitoring of Ditidaht Ha-houlthee and report issues or concerns to the community and relevant agencies.6.Ditidaht Fisheries staff works closely with the Nitinat hatchery staff with activities (e.g., salmon broodstock collections, towing net-pens, feeding net penned fish, etc). 7.Ditidaht Fisheries work with DFO and the Organization's staff to develop an Escapement Salmon Spawning Requirements (ESSR) agreement for Nitinat Lake chinook, coho and chum, where abundances are appropriate.8.Ditidaht Fisheries staff work with DFO for fall salmon stock assessment survey planning.
column36: Contribute to Escapement Estimation,Develop Excess to Spawning Requirements

column3: Stock Assessment and Fisheries Management- Ehattesaht
column4: 1.Ehattesaht Fisheries staff conduct salmon and herring spawning surveys according to survey schedule developed with the Organization's Northern Region Fisheries Biologist and DFO South Coast Stock Assessment (for salmon surveys) as follows: a.Enumerate adult Tahtahtis (Zeballos) River hinkuuas (chum salmon) in September to mid-October by conducting weekly bank or snorkel counts to enumerate spawning salmon from the municipal campground at tidewater to and including the canyon tail spawning bed.  Observation data will be reported to DFO South Coast Stock Assessment  (cc DFO WCVI AFS Manager) on Stream Inspection Logs in-season.  The actual dates and method of reporting to DFO will be included in the AFS Year End Report.b.Ehattesaht staff will work with the Organization's staff to monitor herring spawn distribution, and any food and ceremonial herring fisheries in northern DFO Statistical Area 25.2.Ehattesaht Fisheries staff conduct general monitoring of Ehattesaht Ha-houlthee and report issues or concerns to the community and relevant agencies.3.Ehatteshat Fisheries staff conduct a feasibility study on restoring access for salmon above Zeballos River cascade or falls.4.Ehattesaht Fisheries staff participate in the operation of the Zeballos River hatchery and work closely with the DFO Community Advisor, members of the Zeballos Enhancement Society, youth and community members performing various activities (e.g., salmon broodstock collections, egg incubation, juvenile salmon rearing and releases and may participate in the future in feeding of net penned chum and other species as approved by DFO).5. Ehattesaht Fisheries staff participate in juvenile Chinook salmon micro-trolling sampling activities coordinated through DFO Science (Jessy Bokvist) including all required sampling protocol training.

column3: Stock Assessment and Fisheries Management- Hesquiaht
column4: 1.Hesquiaht Fisheries staff conduct salmon escapement surveys. 2.Hesquiaht Fisheries staff will construct new or re-establish old trails along side some of the streams that will undergo salmon escapement surveys.   3.Hesquiaht Fisheries staff will conduct general monitoring and biological surveys of Hesquiaht Ha-houlthee. 4.Hesquiaht Fisheries will continue to work with Central Westcoast Forest Society (CWFS) on stream restoration work for Ay-yi-sagh Creek, the extent of work completed will be dependent on external funding.  AFS funding pays for Hesquiaht Fisheries staff wages and related expenses, if funding is not available through CWFS.  CWFS pays for any other expenditures required for the project.  Hesquiaht Fisheries only participates in the work if funding is available by CWFS.5. Hesquiaht Fisheries staff will support the construction and installation of a counting fence at Purdon Creek and Hisnit Lake to enumerate adult salmon escapement.

column3: Stock Assessment and Fisheries Management- Mowachaht/Muchalaht
column4: 1.Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff conducts escapement surveys according to survey schedule developed with Uu-a-thluk Regional Biologist and DFO South Coast Stock Assessment staff. a.Enumerate Oktwanch River (Gold River) sockeye and Chinook at Burman River, visual surveys (2-3 surveys) from September to November. b.Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff will implement a bus route CREEL monitoring program for Gold River sockeye fisheries to estimate catch and effort by seine, dipnet and hook and line.2.With the assistance of external funding from the Canada Food Inspection agency (CFIA), Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff conduct bio-toxin monitoring from May to October. 3. Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff conduct general monitoring of Mowachaht/Muchalaht Ha-houlthee and report issues or concerns to the community and relevant agencies.4. Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff works closely with the Nootka Sound Watershed Society (NSWS) and Conuma hatchery staff (e.g., salmon collections, juvenile salmon releases and feeding net pen chinook and chum).5.Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff work with DFO and the Organization's staff on the planning and development of an Excess Salmon to Spawning Requirements (ESSR) agreement for Conuma River chinook, coho and chum if abundances are deemed sufficient.6.Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff works with DFO to coordinate for fall salmon stock assessment survey planning and information flow.
column36: Contribute to Escapement Estimation,Develop Excess to Spawning Requirements

column3: Stock Assessment and Fisheries Management- Nuchatlaht
column4: 1.Nuchatlaht Fisheries staff will monitor, sound, and survey herring spawning waters.2.Nuchatlaht Fisheries staff will monitor and survey spawning streams for salmon.  Reporting live count and carcasses on 2 streams: Espinosa, Savey Creek (Owossista, and Mary Basin, if conditions permit). 3.Nuchatlaht staff will monitor spawning waters for both herring and salmon for activities that may impact spawning areas, such as upland activity disturbances that may affect water, sediment and large wood debris, cover in the "shore zone," and/or sedimentation of salmon spawning habitat.4.Nuchatlaht staff will plan protections for estuaries and watersheds from industrial activities in the form of Salmon Forest Conservation Areas in the Owiissta/Apple Creeks and the Shoomaht/Ransom Creek (Nuu-chah-nulth Salmon Forest Ecological Network watersheds).

column3: Habitat Monitoring and Restoration
column4: Wet'suwet'en Fisheries Staff will conduct habitat protection and monitoring activities to assist in habitat baseline information collection, habitat protection and conservation efforts within the Wet'suwet'en asserted area. 2. The Organization will monitor the functionality of various in-stream structures including culverts and forest service roads within the Morice Watershed. The Organization will review proposals and attend any meetings related to proposed linear development or resource extraction development within the Wet'suwet'en asserted area.

column3: Catch Monitoring and Reporting
column4: Catch Monitoring of all species will continue in Moricetown Canyon.  Data will be used to calculate inseason catch estimates of the Wet'suwet'en Fisheries and be reported weekly to DFO in Prince Rupert and Smithers.

column3: Operational Capacity Funding- Capital Acquisition; Boat hull replacement

column3: Moricetown M&R
column4: Wet'suwet'en Fisheries Staff will continue with the Mark/Recapture Project that provides a population estimate of salmon destined for spawning grounds above the Moricetown Canyon in season, as well as to tag Steelhead for other studies that may occur during the fall and spring.  In addition to tagging the salmonids, data such as sex, length and condition is compiled.  Special emphasis will be given to observe/record the damage conditions of salmon this year with consequent monitoring on the spawning beds. Research suggests that high infection rates with a fungus (Saprolegnia spp.) entering the fish body through net marks and other skin damage causes significant mortalities.   The Mark/Recapture program is mainly funded through stock assessment and the top up of funds is supported through the AFS program.

column3: FSC Fisheries Management
column4: 1.The FC/FT will coordinate catch monitoring and reporting as agreed to in the AFS Agreement. 2.The FC/FT, in consultation with DFO, will develop a detailed operational plan that outlines the proposed fishing activities for the year and the specific fisheries management activities to be undertaken by the Organization.3.The FC/FT will collect all known weekly catch information for all fish including shellfish harvested by the Organization or designate, in a suitable format to the DFO Area Species Coordinators as identified by Jonathan Joe, DFO Resource Manager.4.The FC will employ individual(s) as it deems necessary to undertake catch monitoring and reportings. 5.The FC/FT will maintain records of catch throughout the year for all species possible and summarize information for a final report.6.The FC/FT will assign and manage fishing permits, including communal licences to designated persons and vessels.

column3: Big Bar Landslide response: fish monitoring and tagging program
column4: Up to seven fisheries technicians, three to four from DFO Stock Assessment and two to three from Xwisten will collaboratively angle and tag Chinook salmon as they migrate through the Bridge River area in response to the Big Bar landslide. This element of the monitoring response is integral to determining passage at the Big Bar landslide. Covid-19 procedures have been designed and will be implemented to ensure work is completed in a safe manner.

column3: Fish patrol/catch monitoring program for FSC by the Bridge River Indian Band
column4: Monitors from the Organization will collect the Food, Social and Ceremonial (FSC) salmon catch information at Organization fishing sites during Sockeye and Chinook fishery openings, including fishing activity occurring on the Bridge River.  Monitors will help to educate Xwisten fishers on Xwisten traditional fishing laws by working with family fishing camps.  The Organization provides administrative support to the Xwisten Fish Patrol/Catch Monitoring Program and aids the Program with financial management, including the provision of office space, supplies, utilities, and IT support.

This individual will also monitor fishing activity and interview fishers to collect catch and effort information by conducting in person interviews and effort counts.
